Sentence_location: Received 24 May 2006 , accepted 16 August 2006 Key words: habitat suitability, invertebrate diversity, Latitudinal Gradient Project, microbial diversity, nematodes Introduction Terrestrial ecosystems along the Antarctic Victoria Land coast, from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in the south (78-76°S) to Cape Adare (71°S) in the north, occur across broad scale gradients of biodiversity, climate, and soil properties (Barrett et al. 2006).

Sentence_species: Study site S. lindsayae Eudorylaimus sp. | sp. 2 sp.
Sentence_location: Freeliving soil nematodes and tardigrades are the most abundant and widely distributed animals in continental Antarctica (Freckman & Virginia 1997, Petz 1997, Sinclair 2001, Convey & Wynn-Williams 2002, Sohlenius ef al. 2004, Convey & McInnes 2005, Adams et al. 2006).

Sentence_species: Study site S. lindsayae Eudorylaimus sp. | sp. 2 sp.
Sentence_location: Here we report on work conducted at six sites in northern and southern Victoria Land (Fig. 1), Antarctica in December and January of 2003—2004 (Table I).

Sentence_species: Study site S. lindsayae Eudorylaimus sp. | sp. 2 sp.
Sentence_location: Nematode diversity (H’) was lowest at the extreme ends of the soil productivity gradient at Von Guerard Stream in Taylor Valley and from the most organic rich soils on SeaBee Spit at Cape Hallett (Fig.

Sentence_species: Study site S. lindsayae Eudorylaimus sp. | sp. 2 sp.
Sentence_location: Ninety percent of soils from the Taylor Valley transects near Von Guerard Stream and Green Creek, 95—100% of soil from Luther Vale and 70—90% of the samples examined from Cape Hallett contained nematodes.

Sentence_species: Study site S. lindsayae Eudorylaimus sp. | sp. 2 sp.
Sentence_location: Our data indicate that the largest disparities in N source pools are between soils from Cape Hallett which are influenced by marine N sources, and those from Taylor Valley which have atmospheric to slightly depleted values (Fig. 2).

Sentence_location: Received 24 May 2006 , accepted 16 August 2006 Key words: habitat suitability, invertebrate diversity, Latitudinal Gradient Project, microbial diversity, nematodes Introduction Terrestrial ecosystems along the Antarctic Victoria Land coast, from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in the south (78-76°S) to Cape Adare (71°S) in the north, occur across broad scale gradients of biodiversity, climate, and soil properties (Barrett et al. 2006).

Sentence_species: Heterotardigrada Hypsibius sp. antarcticus davidii Sp. 0
Sentence_location: Freeliving soil nematodes and tardigrades are the most abundant and widely distributed animals in continental Antarctica (Freckman & Virginia 1997, Petz 1997, Sinclair 2001, Convey & Wynn-Williams 2002, Sohlenius ef al. 2004, Convey & McInnes 2005, Adams et al. 2006).

Sentence_species: Heterotardigrada Hypsibius sp. antarcticus davidii Sp. 0
Sentence_location: Here we report on work conducted at six sites in northern and southern Victoria Land (Fig. 1), Antarctica in December and January of 2003—2004 (Table I).

Sentence_species: Heterotardigrada Hypsibius sp. antarcticus davidii Sp. 0

Sentence_species: Plectus antarticus is found only in wet to intermittently wet soils and sediments where salinity is low (Treonis et al. 1999), while Panagrolaimus davidii inhabits the wet, nutrient rich habitats of rookeries and adjacent soils (Porazinska 2002), that are evidently inhospitable to most other metazoans (e.g. Sinclair et al. 2003), as indicated by the lower diversity and biomass of organisms reported here (Fig. 3, Table III).

Sentence_location: Received 24 May 2006 , accepted 16 August 2006 Key words: habitat suitability, invertebrate diversity, Latitudinal Gradient Project, microbial diversity, nematodes Introduction Terrestrial ecosystems along the Antarctic Victoria Land coast, from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in the south (78-76°S) to Cape Adare (71°S) in the north, occur across broad scale gradients of biodiversity, climate, and soil properties (Barrett et al. 2006).

Sentence_location: Received 24 May 2006 , accepted 16 August 2006 Key words: habitat suitability, invertebrate diversity, Latitudinal Gradient Project, microbial diversity, nematodes Introduction Terrestrial ecosystems along the Antarctic Victoria Land coast, from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in the south (78-76°S) to Cape Adare (71°S) in the north, occur across broad scale gradients of biodiversity, climate, and soil properties (Barrett et al. 2006).

Sentence_species: Activity pattern of the moss Hennediella heimii (Hedw.)
Sentence_location: Freeliving soil nematodes and tardigrades are the most abundant and widely distributed animals in continental Antarctica (Freckman & Virginia 1997, Petz 1997, Sinclair 2001, Convey & Wynn-Williams 2002, Sohlenius ef al. 2004, Convey & McInnes 2005, Adams et al. 2006).

Sentence_species: Activity pattern of the moss Hennediella heimii (Hedw.)
Sentence_location: Here we report on work conducted at six sites in northern and southern Victoria Land (Fig. 1), Antarctica in December and January of 2003—2004 (Table I).

Sentence_location: Ninety percent of soils from the Taylor Valley transects near Von Guerard Stream and Green Creek, 95—100% of soil from Luther Vale and 70—90% of the samples examined from Cape Hallett contained nematodes.

Sentence_location: Our data indicate that the largest disparities in N source pools are between soils from Cape Hallett which are influenced by marine N sources, and those from Taylor Valley which have atmospheric to slightly depleted values (Fig. 2).
